Ünfortünately düring the original release, EA's advertising glossed over the RTS aspect, leading many players who were expecting a straight action game to be confüsed and disappointed. Controlling troops from a third-person perspective may not be as flexible as a normal RTS and it does take some getting üsed to, büt it works well for what its intended for in the game.  The müsic in the game and the long list of big name voice actors really help draw yoü into the game. Even thoügh I don't particülarly like most of the bands that are featüred in the game, the müsic fits so well that I can enjoy it anyway. Brütal Legend even has the most perfectly placed song I've ever heard in a game düring one of the cütscenes, thoügh I can't stand listening to it oütside the game.  One problem some people may have is that Jack Black plays the main character. I can assüre yoü that it is not a problem. Eddie Rigg's character is Jack Black playing Jack Black, büt written by Doüble Fine so there is none of Jack Black's classic stüpidity. Ünless yoü cringe at the soünd of Jack Black's voice, I think yoü'll be able to enjoy the game jüst fine.  My only disappointments are that the story felt like it ended rather süddenly when I thoüght it was only halfway throügh, the side missions get rather repetitive, and Doüble Fine doesn't have the fünds to make a seqüel. I wish that Jack Black was in more games. Brütal Legend is an open world, action RPG from Double Fine Productions. Let’s get rocking.  The Good  I think the obvious answer to this is Jack Black.  If you’re a fan of Tenacious D, this game is pretty much Tenacious D: The Game.  The soundtrack is fantastic. Whether you’re cruising around in the Deuce or just wandering around seeing the sights, the blend of well known metal music and original composition is glorious.  There is a satisfyingly ample amount of items for you to unlock in the “Motor Forge”. Their are weapon upgrades for the Deuce, weapon upgrades for your character, and additional attacks to use. There are also purely cosmetic items to acquire, however, like paint jobs, new clothes, and giant stone heads.  There is a large array of enemies for you to hack to pieces as well as indigenous fauna for you to harass. All the designs are brilliant and very much metal influenced.  The story is great, the dialogue is funny, and the game never takes itself to seriously. This is a trait which we don’t see enough these days.  The map is surprisingly big and makes for a good amount of exploration.  The Bad  I’ve got nothing here, sorry.  The Meh  There’s no DLC, so, once the game is over, it’s over. This makes me a sad panda.  Verdict: Yea  If you’re a fan of jack Black, Tenacious D, or metal music, then BL is very much the game for you. You can pick it up in the Steam Store at your earliest convenience. It is money that you won’t regret spending. As always, thanks for reading.

I'll spoil my review right now: Get this game. Get it now.   But only if... You love metal or love music. You love amazing vibrant art styles that ring out so powerfully from almost every other game ever made you'll be in awe the first time (and quite a few times after) you see it. From classic, classic metal visions of twisted earths with massive beasts with huge metal jaws, covered in spikes to sly slinky monsters that slither through black water towards you. This covers almost every genre of 'Metal' that exists.  This game is just pure briliance, and what else can you expect from Tim Schafer, creator of Psychonauts? (Well, except him being a complete jerk.) Jack Black alone makes the game worth playing, but expect to run in to many, MANY 'Rock Gods' on your journey. Like... Well, I won't ruin it. But if you're a fan of Black Sabbath...  The game isn't as perfect as I say it is, so I've got a few things to complain about so let me point out the major flaws.  This is the big one: The game transitions from being primarily a hack n' slash to a... RTS esque battling system. You still control Eddie (voice by Jack Black, duh.) and can still run around on foot (or drive around in car) and kick ♥♥♥. But you'll also be responsible for taking control points, commanding units and making sure you keep your resources up. Don't worry, it's NO WHERE near as complicated as most RTS games, but the change takes time to get used to.  A few of the later 'battles' can become very frustrating due to how some enemies work and how you are positioned to them. Mostly since you start with almost nothing and the enemies can start out full pelt. Especially on higher difficulties.  In fact, all I really have to complain about is the combat... But unfortunately, since that's what the gameplay is... It's a big one.   This game has done almost everything perfectly. The music, the visuals, the cameos, the voice acting, the 'solos' you learn and the story. The animated cutscenes you have to seek out yourself to learn the backround are gorgeous, the scenery is pure eye candy. It's truly a fantastic game.   Unfortunately, the combat itself will ruin the game for a lot of people. If you can adapt to it, (It's seriously not as bad as you think, but I have to be fair.) this game will be somewhere on your top games of all time.  Summary/TL;DR: I am in love with this game. It's gorgeous, in fact, some of it made me tear up a little.. But, it's flawed. It really is. Play this game if you want one of the greatest (top 5 easily) stylizations that's ever been in a video game and most likely ever will. Play this if you want FANTASTIC voice work. (For gadzooks, it has Tim Curry!) Play this if you want a great value for your money and to be sucked in to an amazing world that left me depressed for a full week after I finished it... Because there was no more, and most likely never will be.   I give this game an 3.75 out of 5.

This game is just awesome: you've got blood, fire, noise and metal with a soft touch of Aetulia's singing. The game really makes you believe that there was an age of metal (which would be awesome, though) with demons, titans, Ormagoden himself and humans. If anyone would take this seriously, it might even become a religion (or at least another evolution theory) for some.  It's amazing that this game has been released with all the good ideas, I'd really want to see a sequel to it with the ability to make Eddie fly when roaming all around the map, although it would be easier to find secrets that way. The limits of the map aren't natural when talking about exploring the game, though: you hit an invisible wall at some point, it feels like the map is made out of many open-sided boxes. But all of these improvements would work even better with separate campaigns for every main character: Eddie, normal/drowned Ophelia(s, spoilers, sorry), Doviculus, that glam hairstyle wearing Lionwhyte, maybe even Rignarok with Succoria, and the future characters, if any. Even though it's far fetched, it would make a great addition to the game. And, of course, a longer story - I've beaten this game in 8 hours straight. Must. Have. More.  So in short, the game is already epic, some improvements would work in favor of the game (unless it becomes worse like what happens with some game series - the writers get carried away), the story pulls you into the game and holds you tight until you ultimately finish the game with every achievement unlocked. The songs are picked pretty well, too. In the name of every metalhead in the world, Tim Schafer, please release a sequel!

Brutal Legend seems to have a lot of unique things about it. It's obvious heavy metal world, the blending of RTS and normal third person RPG combat, and lots of different troops to command. However, despite the potential, it fails to execute these elements properly.  Open World- The open world system common to rpgs does have some good aspects about it. There are things to find that give you rewards, and the environments, while generic, do vary quite a bit (you have grasslands to desert to snowy areas and so on). There are many probles however. First of all, it doesn't incorporate the heavy metal theme quite as well as one would imagine. Sure, there are momuments and such relating to music, but most of the areas just seem bland.   Why Open World?- The bigger problem, however, is that there's not much point in having the open world. Unlike other rpgs, this game only has an open world to store a few, repetitive side quests, and some collectables that give Fire Tributes (the game's currency) and more songs to play (abilities per say), all of which could have easily been contained within something like a mission system.   Compared to Other Open Worlds- In a worthwhile rpg, there would be a variety of secrets and such to reward exploring, while in Brutal Legend, you'll only find a few abilities that can sometimes be pretty useless and small amounts of fire tribute. The only interesting thing are the bits of lore you can discover, but this isn't nearly enough content to justify the usage of an open world. In other rpgs, you'll find many unique and interesting wildlife/enemies/npcs that spice up the gameplay. In Brutal Legend, there will be only a small handfull of wildlife in a large part of the map, without even as much as pockets of specific types being spread out to add to the environment. You will find npcs around, but they only serve to give you sidequests or give a line of dialogue. There are enemies, but it's pointless to kill them, and they are of no threat as you will be in your car most of the time.  'Driving'- Ah, the car, the Deuce, or the piece of trash (whatever you want to call it). The problems listed above could have been passable if it were not for the fact you have to use your car most of the time. The controls on it are finicky and seemingly random. Turning is, by far the main problem. Most of the time, holding down A and D won't turn much at all, but sometimes if you do as much as press on of them once you'll go 90 degrees in that direction. This problem only adds on to the next problem in that your car feels completely weightless. Say, if you graze a rock, instead of holding its ground and only wavering for a bit, the Deuce will turn 90 degrees and go completely off course. Fantastic. And this only adds to the next problem in that the camera doesn't move with your car. Now, I know some games with vehicles allow you to move your camera freely all the time, but here, well, let's just go back to the original situation. Due to bad turning mechanics, you hit the edge of a hill or something. Due to the weightlessness of the car, instead of keeping on track, it starts turning towards the mountain. Due to the non-fixed camera, you keep on holding W to make your car go foward, only for it to turn to the hill within a matter of seconds, and at top speed, your car drives (or attempts to drive) up the hill. If there was a fixed angle, as soon as the car wavers towards the mountain, you would notice and press A or D respectively to combat the turn. These problems make it a pain the traverse the world, and you HAVE to use the Deuce as there's no fast travel system.  Combat- Definently not as bad as driving, but it could use some work. So you have two main attacks: a melee attack and an auto-target long ranged one...and that's about it. There are combos that you get and unlock and songs that you can play, but it all amounts to the same result (songs are okay, but combos aren't worth remembering). Enemies attack differently, but there's no real strategy to beat them with. Unlike other rpgs, there's no weakpoints or vulnerability to attacks or really anything. It's just hack 'n slash. Okay, but what about those rts elements? Surely those will make up for it! Well, again, it's okay. Better, but still just okay. During battles you can summon troops and all, but you're limited on commands on what to do with them. And you can't really split up your army easily, nor do you have to as the enemies and terrain are just as bland. So battles will just be:   Summon troops--> Attack--> Summon more troops--> Attack--> Repeat  All it comes down to is 'Who has the bigger pile of troops?'. Okay, but maybe the troops are so complex that having advanced control of your army isn't needed! Again, not really. They are different, and there's even specific missions dedicated to most of the troops, but it just comes down to spamming as much troops as possible. As long as you have enough melee and ranged and maybe a healer, then you're fine. You can't really summon troops to counter your specific enemies or anything complex like that.  Sidequests- As said before, there are sidequests. Every once in a while you'll find a unique quest, but most are just bland repeats of a simple objective. So in my gameplay, I've really only played at most 6 different sidequests. And these sidequests, while different, are just as bland as combat battles. Also, there's a questline for racing. It's not fun. At all. (I could talk about racing but this review would probably be 50% longer)  Fire Tributes- You get these by exploring and doing sidequests, and you can only spend them at Motor Forges for upgrades to things like the Deuce or your attacks (and for some reason Motor Forges aren't even introduced in a tutorial or main storyline). I wouldn't say these upgrades are minor, but again, they're bland and don't change up gameplay much, only help you progress by giving more DPS or something. Also, you get a crap load of fire tributes over time, so doing all the sidequests or exploring isn't neccesary or rewarded much (going along with the problem with the open world).  Story- The story is really what's making me finish the game. It's not groundbreaking or overly good or anything, but like any story it's nice to know how it progresses. One redeemable thing I like is how it shows the journey of the player and the npcs moving around rather than there just being one main base you always return to. Unlike sidequests, the main missions also give much different objectives, but they're just as bland.  Music- Adds to the environment, of course. I mean, it's a game based on metal. There's not much to say other than that the music exists. Personally, I like the selections, but if you can't tolerate the genre, then you shouldn't even bother getting the game.  Main Probems- All of what I'm saying boils down to this: skilless combat and crappy driving. The two main elements of the game are not executed too well. The combat does some unique things, but feels so bland and skilless, ultimately taking away from the other aspects like the sidequests. If this were the only problem, then the game would still be commendable (for it's price, anyways), but the driving just ruins it. It destroys a whole line of racing quests, isn't fun, and makes the open world system feel more unneccesary than it already is. The driving is what truly makes the game not worth it.

I would love to rate this game higher, but I am affraid I can not. The question of course is why, because the game certainly does have several things that speak for it. If you are cruising Metal music (of different genres of metal) greets your ears. Something I enjoy and in fact made me appreciate some artists better, but certainly not for everyone. Okay so that gives it a rather niche public, but that doesn't make it bad does it? No, it doesn't.  However, the game also has real time combat and does so in a the old Warcraft/Starcraft format, but has the view not topdown but on you as well as you are a important player. With no pause function, bad overview, the fact that you need to fight as well as command constantly - because the AI is just horrible - makes it stressful. A shrill constrast to the rest. The problem is that this game is fun, looks nicely, has good humor, but was not properly developed for combat with mouse and keyboard.  Thus, the game has its niche in which it does well. However, if you do not like this niche or do not own a controller, I would say it is not worth the frustation of the combat and quirky controls (even with remapping!) - because that is the opposite of what the game is intended to be and would be a dissappointment over an otherwise well intended and decently executed (mainly music, humor and graphic wise) game.

Sadly, most games with ambitious design decisions suffer from poor execution, having no predecessors to draw from. Brutal Legend is an exception. For those who haven't played Grim Fandango or Psychonaughts, Double Fine is known for an exemplary degree of humor and polish. Brutal Legend is no different.  If you couldn't tell from the thumbnail, the game is thick with heavy-metal themes. Everything from environments, units, soundtrack, voice actors, to passing references all is in some way a tribute to metal, both old and new.  The gameplay is a refreshing mix of RTS, hack and slash, and open world. I wouldn't go so far as to say it's a masterpiece in any one of those areas, but it would be difficult to find a gamer without something to do in this game. If you're not proficient in one area, the others will more than make up for your difficulties. Unit effectiveness can be greatly increased by 'double-teaming', or controlling a single unit, adding abilities or boosting stats. The game is littered with combos and tactical nuance for 3rd-person RPG fans to dig into. For the exploring types, the landscape is thick with collectibles, of both the stat-boosting and artwork/music varieties.  If I had to present any flaw with the game, it would be the length, only the staunchest of completionists will get more than 15 hours out of a single campaign. It is obvious that budget or time constraints forced Double Fine to thin out the latter half. Initially, the story and character-development is carefully paced, and suddenly it's turned up to 11, characters entering and leaving the stage quickly. Thankfully, this is only in quantity rather than quantity, for every piece of content in the final game from story to idle dialogue was masterfully done.

This review could go either way, so I hit 'Do Not Recommend' to balance out the average a little more toward the 7/10 or so this game deserves.  While elegantly made, with great environments and some great humour, the Brutal Legend really falls flat in a few areas. If you enjoy Jack Black and his movies, this game will probably feel like a good length. To me, it felt like they could have cut a third to a half of the game and no one would have noticed. In particular, the lengthy time needed to unlock units, progress the story, or get enough fire for the upgrades takes forever. The story seemed good, but stretched too far out. Unless you roll straight from story mission to story mission, you're likely to have forgotten the plot or why you ever cared in the first place because of all the filler missions in between.  If Double Fine had instead focused on EITHER an RTS or a third-person brawler/adventure/sandbox, the game would feel so much better. Instead, you find yourself repeating the same moves with the same character, rolling into a terribly designed RTS where your immediate objective is to get out as fast as possible to hop back in your car, summoned with the same boring chord that you'll use fifty billion times. Oh, and your car remains the same; some upgrades, but don't go looking for even a bike (except for 2 minutes in one mission), because that car is it. I'd enjoy at least a little variety. Given the strength of the third-person adventuring, Double Fine could have cut the RTS sections totally, shortened the game considerably, and still had an awesome title.  Finally, if you don't enjoy Jack Black, his voice will make you want to murder him. The intro to the game has no bearing on the game itself (why is Black in a record store? Why is this record there? Why are we watching this dumb video whenever you start the game? And best of all, why should we care?), and Black could only be arsed to record some lines, which means you'll hear many Riggs' lines over and over and over. There's only so much self-depreciating 'hurr hurr look at me I'm just a roadie in the background but you're hot wanna bang oh no ok that's cool I'm still better than anyone else but I'm in the background' that you can take before wanting to garrote yourself with guitar strings.  In summary:  PROS: Good humour (the first time you hear it), great environment, great art, killer soundtrack, some excellent sections and bosses.  CONS: Stretched far beyond reasonable game length, the repetitious missions and humour ('Hey, who we ambushing?' 'BAD GUYS!' x200), the half-♥♥♥♥♥ game setup split between combat and RTS, graphical glitches that screw up any hair (in particular LionWhyte's, which is sad, as it's his only real feature), predictable and trite storyline, Black's humour gets old really fast. Multiplayer is a crappy port of the RTS section, with all of its weaknesses. WHERE'S THE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ MINIMAP? No real reason to upgrade beyond the basics (machine guns for the car, more combos if you want them, the mountain man look).

so... brutal legend. it's not a bad game, but it's not good, either.  things i liked - art direction - soundtrack - backstory - free roam  things i didn't like - awful optimisation. this game is rather old now, and i know it was made for 360 and ps3 but hot damn, this is a terrible port in terms of how it actually runs. - the badly implemented RTS. i knew about it, and knew people hated it, but i didn't know just how integral it was to the main game. the stage battles are the boss fights, after you gather your first few units. it felt more like a prototype than a finished product, very, very tanky feeling. - driving controls, way too much understeer - input seems to be unresponsive sometimes - no way to get unstuck unless you exit to the main menu - upon death (or returning to main menu), you're taken back to the last motor forge/significant quest point regardless of where the last autosave was, meaning if you last exited a motor forge at the left most side of the map but die on the right most side, you'll have to travel ALL the way back. - very little to do outside of the main quest line. it's literally just ambush quests and kill quests. i think that's pretty poor for an open world game. there is hunting for the collectables, but there should have been much more fun/interesting interactions with world and the people in it. - completion of the game seems to remove all your ironheade buddies from bladehenge and they're just forever roaming, killing rival clans...  i think it's obvious the game was rushed, and if double fine had taken their time this would have been absolutely perfect. a shame they didn't seem to bother rectifying anything for the pc port. only get this if you find it on sale.

tl;dr: This game is a great blend of Action/Hack-and-Slash and RTS gameplay with a style that ensures that it ages well as time passes. Definitely worth getting on sale.   The stage battle missions in the game relies heavily on your ability to manage your army, while making sure that you yourself are active enough in the battle to ensure that your enemies don't get a leg up on you; only your units can damage buildings and free resource nodes, but you have to step in to capture these points, and regularly need to come in to help take down more powerful enemy units. The rest of the game provides a good blend of smaller skirmish-type battles, solo missions, and driving missions to protect your tour bus. The world is very well-designed, and the graphics still hold up well for a game that was originally released on console in 2009 (I believe most cutscenes are in-engine, so modern machines won't have the drawback of poor video quality cutscenes). The writing is exactly what you would expect from a game where Jack Black voices the main character; 'Who we ambushing?' 'Bad guys. Wanna help?' Overall, this game is a great buy if you can find it on sale or in a bundle, as the only real negative is that the game has a fairly steep learning curve for those unfamiliar with RTS games.
